item.title: NASA’s Juno Mission Provides Groundbreaking Insights Into Volcanic Heat Of Io, Jupiter’s Largest Moon - News18
item.description:
NASA’s Juno Mission Provides Groundbreaking Insights Into Volcanic Heat Of Io, Jupiter’s Largest Moon

Date: December 17, 2024

Source: News18

The Juno mission has shed light on the volcanic activity of Io, revealing that its volcanoes are powered by localized magma chambers rather than a global magma ocean, changing our understanding of its geology.

  • Io is the most volcanically active body in the solar system with over 400 active volcanoes.
  • The volcanic eruptions are powered by tidal flexing from Jupiter's gravitational influence.
  • Data collected by Juno indicates localized magma chambers provide energy for the eruptions.
  • These findings could influence the study of other potentially habitable moons like Europa and Enceladus.
“The squeezing generates heat to the extent that Io’s insides are melting and erupting,” - Scott Bolton, Juno’s principal investigator.

The Juno mission’s discoveries not only clarify the nature of volcanic activity on Io but also invite a reevaluation of how tidal forces impact other celestial bodies.

item.title: Boltz-1: A model to predict biomolecular structures - Tech Explorist
item.description:
Boltz-1: A Model to Predict Biomolecular Structures

Publication Date: December 17, 2024
Source: MIT News

MIT scientists have introduced Boltz-1, an innovative open-source AI model aimed at predicting biomolecular structures with high accuracy, similar to existing models while encouraging community collaboration.

Key Points:

  • Boltz-1 is the first fully open-source model achieving performance on par with AlphaFold3.
  • The model was developed by the MIT Jameel Clinic for Machine Learning in Health.
  • Researchers focused on improving prediction efficiency and accuracy through new algorithms.
  • Boltz-1's entire development pipeline is open-sourced for further scientific collaboration.
  • MIT researchers call for community contributions to enhance Boltz-1 continuously.
“We hope for this to be a starting point for the community...This is not the end of the line. We want as much contribution from the community as we can get.” - Gabriele Corso

Conclusion: Boltz-1 represents a significant leap in the field of biomolecular prediction, fostering open collaboration among researchers for future advancements.

item.title: NASA’s DaVinci probe ancient terrain, lower atmosphere of Venus - News9 LIVE
item.description:
NASA is dispatching the DaVinci probe to Venus in the early 2030s. The spacecraft will be the first to image the surface in 40 years.

Publication Date: New Delhi

Source: Science News

NASA is developing its Deep Atmosphere Venus Investigation of Noble gases, Chemistry, and Imaging (DaVinci) mission to Venus that consists of two elements, a spacecraft to conduct flybys and a probe that will descend into the atmosphere of the Earth. The mission is slotted for launch in the early 2030s. The probe will be the first to investigate the ancient portions of the Venusian terrain, known as tessera, with a particular focus on alpha Region.

  • The DaVinci probe will examine chemical composition in the lower regions of Venus's atmosphere.
  • Measurements will be conducted from an altitude of 27 kilometers to the surface.
  • The mission aims to illuminate the history of water on Venus and understand its greenhouse gas effect.
  • Multiple missions, including VERITAS and ESA's Envision, will probe Venus alongside DaVinci.
“Understanding more about Venus can help scientists better understand the dynamics of our own atmosphere, as well as the atmospheres of distant exoplanets.”

DaVinci will use a parachute to slow its descent, allowing its instruments to gather data effectively as it explores Venus in depth.

item.title: NASA's James Webb Telescope spots 138 new asteroids, including Earth-threatening ones - India TV News
item.description:
NASA's James Webb Telescope Discovers 138 New Asteroids, Including Potentially Hazardous Ones

Publication Date: December 9, 2024 | Source: Nature

Astronomers using data from the James Webb Space Telescope have uncovered a significant number of new asteroids located in the main belt between Mars and Jupiter, with some on orbits that could bring them close to Earth.

  • A total of 138 new asteroids were identified.
  • Some of these asteroids could pose a threat to Earth.
  • Discovery made possible by revisiting old JWST data initially aimed at the TRAPPIST-1 star system.
  • Largest asteroids are compared in size to several stadiums.
  • The findings may lead to increased understanding and observation of smaller asteroids.
“This is a sign of a new population regime of asteroids,” said Julien de Wit, an Associate Professor of Planetary Science at MIT.

Looking forward, continued observations may reveal thousands more asteroids, enhancing monitoring for potential threats to Earth.

item.title: Ursid Meteor Shower 2024: Dates, Viewing Tips, and Best Times - Gadgets 360
item.description:
Ursid Meteor Shower 2024: Dates, Viewing Tips, and Best Times

Publication Date: 2024-12-21 Source: Gadgets 360

The Ursids meteor shower will peak on the night of December 21 to 22, 2024, coinciding with the winter solstice in the Northern Hemisphere, with an expected display of around 10 meteors per hour.

  • The Ursids will be active from December 17 to 26.
  • Best viewing is expected before dawn on December 22.
  • The meteors originate from Comet 8P/Tuttle.
  • Holding a location away from artificial lights can enhance viewing experiences.
  • Observers should allow their eyes to adjust to the dark.
"Meteor showers like the Ursids are best observed with the unaided eye."

In conclusion, despite the competition from the Geminids earlier in the month, the Ursids offer a captivating skywatching opportunity for fans of astronomy.

item.title: Trappist-1 b may host an atmosphere after all - News9 LIVE
item.description:
Trappist-1 b may host an atmosphere after all

Publication Date: New Delhi Source: Science News

The Trappist-1 system is one of the most promising for hosting extraterrestrial life. Recent observations previously indicated that Trappist-1 b lacks an atmosphere, but new interpretations suggest otherwise, highlighting the complexities of studying distant exoplanets.

  • The team suggests Trappist-1 b may have a dynamic crust influenced by tectonics and volcanism.
  • Contrary to past studies, the planet could have a thick carbon dioxide-rich atmosphere.
  • The James Webb Space Telescope is crucial in exoplanet studies but requires longer observational periods for conclusive data.
“Contrary to previous ideas, there are conditions under which the planet could have a thick atmosphere rich in carbon dioxide.” - Thomas Henning

This revelation underscores the ongoing challenges in exoplanetary science and the evolving understanding of planet atmospheres.

item.title: Nasa’s Mars mission will plug into nuke power - The Times of India
item.description:
Nasa’s Mars Mission Will Utilize Nuclear Power

Date: October 14, 2023

Source: Times of India

Nasa has announced plans to use nuclear power for upcoming crewed missions to Mars, with a potential launch around 2035. This decision supports the vision of establishing a sustainable human presence on the Red Planet.

  • Nasa has chosen fission (nuclear) power as the primary energy source for Mars missions.
  • This decision is part of the “2024 Architecture Concept Review Cycle” aimed at long-term exploration in deep space.
  • Nuclear power is preferred over solar due to its consistent power generation, especially during dust storms on Mars.
  • A mission with two crew members would require at least 10 kilowatts of energy, while larger crews would need hundreds of kilowatts.
“Fission can provide consistent power generation for a wide range of potential landing sites round-the-clock and during dust storms.”

This initiative marks a critical step towards ensuring energy reliability for future Mars explorations, showcasing Nasa's commitment to advancing deep space technology.

item.title: NASA James Webb Space Telescope reveals rocky planet formation in harsh environments - The Times of India
item.description:
NASA's James Webb Space Telescope Reveals Rocky Planet Formation in Harsh Environments

Published on: December 16, 2023, Source: The Astrophysical Journal

The recent findings from NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope reveal that planets can form and survive in environments that are much harsher than previously believed. This challenges long-held theories about planet formation.

  • James Webb Telescope findings suggest long-lasting planet-forming disks exist around stars with low heavy elements.
  • Planet-forming disks can survive for tens of millions of years, providing ample time for planets to form.
  • Research challenges traditional models that argue planets cannot form in metal-poor environments.
  • Implications extend to understanding planet formation in the early universe, potentially dating back to shortly after the Big Bang.
“This implies that planets could have begun forming at a much earlier stage in the universe’s history than previously thought.” - Guido De Marchi

The discovery revolutionizes our understanding of planet formation and opens new avenues for research in astronomy, particularly regarding the early universe and the origins of our solar system.

item.title: Three asteroids are on their way to Earth - India Today
item.description:
Three Asteroids Approaching Earth Soon

Publication Date: November 2024   |   Source: India Today

On December 17, 2024, three asteroids will approach Earth, presenting unique scientific research opportunities. The asteroids include 2022 YO1, 2024 XR6, and 2024 XC17, all deemed non-threatening to the planet.

  • Asteroids 2022 YO1, 2024 XR6, and 2024 XC17 are set for close encounters with Earth.
  • 2022 YO1 will approach within 7,56,604 kilometers and measures 2.6–5.9 meters.
  • 2024 XR6, measuring 12–26 meters, will pass at about 15 million kilometers away.
  • 2024 XC17, measuring 9.1–20 meters, will come within 7.8 million kilometers.
  • All asteroids pose no threat to Earth and will provide research opportunities for astronomers.
Astronomers are tracking the asteroids with advanced systems to study their trajectories, sizes, and compositions, enhancing understanding of near-Earth dynamics.

The upcoming flybys of these asteroids present an excellent opportunity for scientific observation without endangering Earth.

item.title: NASA funded commercial space station Starlab meets crucial developmental milestones - News9 LIVE
item.description:
NASA's Starlab Space Station Achieves Key Development Milestones

Date: December 2024 | Source: Science News

Starlab is a NASA-funded commercial space station initiative aimed at ensuring the continuity of scientific operations as the International Space Station approaches retirement. The project has successfully met multiple developmental milestones.

  • Starlab has passed reviews for its habitat structural test article, systems design, integrated operations, and structural test plan.
  • The structural test article verifies the design of the space station's habitation module.
  • Proper safety reviews and preliminary design reviews are expected to complete by the end of the year.

Low Earth Orbit Destination

NASA is also partnering with private companies like Axiom Space and Boeing for developing additional commercial low Earth orbit destinations, reinforcing its foothold in microgravity research.

item.title: Christmas in space: Sunita Williams and crew in holiday mood as Dragon departs - India Today
item.description:
Christmas in Space: Sunita Williams and Crew Celebrate the Holidays Aboard the ISS

Published On: Dec 17, 2024
Source: India Today

Sunita Williams and her crew aboard the International Space Station (ISS) are celebrating Christmas in space with festive traditions and outreach efforts.

  • The crew is sharing holiday traditions and festive cheer despite being far from Earth.
  • They plan to enjoy special meals and connect with family via video calls.
  • They are participating in educational outreach, engaging with students on Earth.
  • The SpaceX Dragon capsule recently undocked, carrying supplies and gifts for the crew.
NASA said that after re-entering Earth's atmosphere, the spacecraft will make a parachute-assisted splashdown off the coast of Florida.

Williams reflects on the significance of celebrating the holidays in space, highlighting the stunning views of Earth and the unique experiences they share.

item.title: Twins were the norm for our ancient primate ancestors — one baby at a time had evolutionary advantages - Down To Earth Magazine
item.description:
Twins Were Common for Ancient Primate Ancestors, Study Finds

Date & Source: Publication Date: Not specified, Source: Not specified

Twins have been rare in human history and for that reason can seem special. Many cultures associate twins with health and vitality, while others see them as a philosophical reminder of the duality of life and death, good and evil.

Our recent research suggests that twins were actually the norm much further back in primate evolution, rather than an unusual occurrence worthy of note. Despite the fact that almost all primates today, including people, usually give birth to just one baby, our most recent common ancestor, which roamed North America about 60 million years ago, likely gave birth to twins as the standard.

  1. Twins were the norm for ancient primate ancestors about 60 million years ago.
  2. The switch to singletons occurred early on, at least 50 million years ago, and was advantageous for primates to develop only one fetus per pregnancy.
  3. Having a single offspring allowed for larger bodies and brains, crucial for complex learning.
  4. Rates of twins have almost doubled in the US over the past 50 years due to advances in assistive reproductive technologies.
  5. Having twins today can be dangerous for both the mother and babies, with more than half of all twins in the US being born prematurely.
Our findings don’t mean that having twins today is a disadvantage — although, as a mother of multiples, Tesla can certainly say it’s not easy. But having twins today is quite a different experience from our tiny primate ancestors birthing in the trees 60 million years ago.

Despite these risks, our research shows that twins are a critical part of our genetic history.

item.title: 5 mesmerising star formation images captured by NASA James Webb Space Telescope - HT Tech
item.description:
5 Mesmerising Star Formation Images Captured by NASA James Webb Space Telescope

Publication Date: December 17, 2024 | Source: HT TECH

This article presents five stunning images of star formation, beautifully captured by the NASA James Webb Space Telescope, shedding light on the fascinating processes involved in star formation.

  • Star formation can occur through various means such as the collision of different molecular clouds and galaxies.
  • It takes between 10,000 to 100,000 years for a star to reach its fully formed shape.
  • The Hubble and Webb telescopes have unveiled mesmerizing images showcasing young star clusters and star formation regions.
  • Notable regions explored include NGC 602 and NGC 604, which are hotbeds of stellar activity.
  • The Rho Ophiuchi cloud complex is highlighted as the closest star-forming region to Earth.
“These images demonstrate the ongoing processes of star formation and the beauty of the universe.”

This collection of images reminds us of the vastness and complexity of our universe and the exciting discoveries facilitated by advanced space telescopes.

item.title: Jupiter's Hellish Moon Isn't Powered by a Hidden Ocean of Magma, Study Finds - ScienceAlert
item.description:
Jupiter's Moon Io Powered by Localized Magma Chambers, Not a Global Ocean

Published on: October 2023, Source: Science Alert

New research indicates that the volcanic activity on Jupiter's moon Io is not driven by a hidden ocean of magma, as previously suggested. Instead, scientists have found that the volcanoes are fed by a network of small magma chambers within a primarily solid mantle.

  • The study used NASA's Juno spacecraft images and gravitational data.
  • It counters previous theories suggesting a global magma ocean under Io’s surface.
  • The findings have implications for understanding planetary formation and evolution.
  • Io's surface is covered with volcanic remnants from its numerous eruptions.
  • This research provides insights into tidal heating processes in celestial bodies.
“This constant flexing creates immense energy, which literally melts portions of Io's interior,” says Scott Bolton, a space physicist involved in the study.

The research highlights the complexity of tidal heating effects and broadens the understanding of volcanic processes on other celestial bodies.

item.title: Is Earth at risk? James Webb Space Telescope discovered many tiny asteroids in the asteroid belt between - The Times of India
item.description:
James Webb Space Telescope Detects Numerous Tiny Asteroids Between Mars and Jupiter

Date: October 2023 Source: Space.com

Astronomers using the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) have discovered a large number of tiny asteroids in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter, raising concerns about their potential risk to Earth.

  • Discovery of an unexpectedly high number of tiny asteroids in the asteroid belt.
  • The asteroids are significantly smaller than those that caused the extinction of the dinosaurs but pose a greater risk due to their higher collision frequency with Earth.
  • A new computational method developed by astronomers allows for improved detection of these small asteroids using GPU technology.
  • Among the discoveries, six asteroids have orbits that could potentially intersect with Earth's orbit.
  • The JWST's infrared capabilities enhance the detection of faint and fast-moving asteroids.
  • Future observations using JWST and other advanced telescopes, like the Vera C. Rubin Observatory, will enhance tracking and identification of small asteroids.
“This newfound ability to detect small asteroids ... is a critical step toward improving planetary defense.”

The advancements made by the JWST in detecting small asteroids highlight the growing importance of planetary defense strategies and monitoring potential threats to Earth.
